DOC.HEAD: NAACP Figure Tries To Keep Normal Pace in Face of Death Threat
With AM-Mail Bombs, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When a group that claimed responsibility for two mail bomb assassinations made a blanket death threat against NAACP officials, that blanket might well have been dropped over Earl Shinhoster's head. Shinhoster, Southeastern regional director for the NAACP, has emerged as a potential target of someone's apparent grudge against his group and the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. ``I've always understood very clearly the security implications for what I do,'' Shinhoster said Friday night. ``These folks are deadly serious, whether this is isolated, whether it's one or two issues involved,'' Shinhoster said. ``I'm less concerned about reasons here as I am about how to deal with it.'' ``I'm really concerned for Shinhoster and others with the NAACP,'' said Charles King, an Atlanta civil rights activist. ``This is very serious for them, but the rest of us ... I don't think we're that much at risk.'' Shinhoster's jurisdiction in the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People includes Georgia, Alabama and Florida, the three states that make up the 11th Circuit of the federal appeals court. Package bombs killed 11th U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance on Dec. 16, and Savannah, Ga., lawyer and civil rights activist Robert Robinson two days later. Two others were intercepted at the 11th Circuit building in Atlanta and the Jacksonville, Fla., NAACP office. In August, a mailed tear-gas bomb went off in Shinhoster's office, injuring eight people _ at about the time letters declaring war against the 11th Circuit popped up at several television stations. And a threatening letter _ much like the one in which ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System'' claimed responsibility for the bombs that killed Vance and Robinson _ arrived at Shinhoster's office shortly after the tear-gas did. ``I think it was very specific and targeted,'' Shinhoster said. ``I don't think it was happenstance.'' Authorities have confirmed that the letters appear to come from someone involved in the mail bombings. Shinhoster said that link means he probably will be greeted by guards, police and FBI agents wherever he goes, at least in the immediate future. On Friday, he said, police officers met him at the airport in Savannah, where he went for a funeral. ``When I got back on the plane, they put me on the plane,'' he said. James D. Williams, national spokesman for the Baltimore-based NAACP, said the organization has taken extra security precautions he would not specify. ``We believe that this latest incident is an effort to intimidate our association, to strike fear in our hearts,'' said NAACP executive director Benjamin Hooks. ``It will not succeed. We intend to go about our business, but we will most certainly be taking precautions.''
